SPEAKER_06: I had been in the army for three years,
until I got kicked out...

SPEAKER_06: because there were some corpses
that had to be buried.

SPEAKER_06: My lieutenant gave me
the order to bury them.

SPEAKER_06: But I didn’t. Instead I sold them
to some people who approached me.
SPEAKER_06: They wanted me to sell them.
SPEAKER_06: That they would use them for a play...
SPEAKER_06: or something like that.

SPEAKER_06: They told me not to worry,
that nobody would find out.

SPEAKER_06: So I believed them and
I sold them the corpses.

SPEAKER_06: I found out later what they
were really going to do with them.
SPEAKER_06: They would disguise them

SPEAKER_06: and leave them in the mountains as
if they would have died in combat.

SPEAKER_06: I kept silence until they were
declared as "false positives".
SPEAKER_06: MUTE FIRE

SPEAKER_06: On February 10th 1906, four men
tried to murder the president of Colombia.

SPEAKER_06: The staging of that event, was the
beginning of cinema in the country.

SPEAKER_06: They told me not to worry,
that nobody would find out.

SPEAKER_06: So I believed them and
sold them the corpses.

SPEAKER_06: I found out later what they
were going to do with them.
SPEAKER_06: That they would disguise them...

SPEAKER_06: …and leave them on the mountains
as if they would have died in combat.

SPEAKER_06: I kept silence until they were
declared as "false positives".
SPEAKER_01: The newspaper "Correo Nacional",
SPEAKER_01: published in Bogotá on March 6th, 1906,
SPEAKER_01: the exact and vivid account of the execution of four men
SPEAKER_01: for the attempt of murder of the General Rafael Reyes,
SPEAKER_01: by that time president of Colombia.
SPEAKER_01: Marco Arturo Salgar, Carlos Roberto Gonzalez, Juan Ortiz and Fernando Aguilar.
SPEAKER_01: were the four men sentenced to death, and in consequence
SPEAKER_01: shot in the same place where they committed the crime.
SPEAKER_01: The account, whose author's name remains unknown,
SPEAKER_01: is extremely detailed.
SPEAKER_01: For example, he describes one by one the kind of hat that each condemned was wearing.
SPEAKER_01: It’s worth quoting the whole fragment:
SPEAKER_01: "They were all wearing black: Salgar wore a straight wing cinnamon hat.
SPEAKER_01: Aguilar wore a Panama hat.
SPEAKER_01: Gonzales, a black Tyrolean hat.
SPEAKER_01: And Ortiz wore a black hard hat."
SPEAKER_01: The reporter also collects a series of interviews.
SPEAKER_01: The most striking is perhaps, the one from the Captain of Executions, who just says,
SPEAKER_01: in a serious tone I'd guess: "Nothing is sacred".
SPEAKER_01: The reporter states: "The shooting proceeds as normal.
SPEAKER_01: Given the signal with his sword by the Captain of Executions,
SPEAKER_01: the first round of shooting resounds from the rifles.
SPEAKER_01: Afterwards, a group of doctors approaches
SPEAKER_01: and certify that the condemned are still breathing,
SPEAKER_01: and give the order for a second shooting,
SPEAKER_01: which ends with the immediate entrance of the four coffins
SPEAKER_01: to transport the corpses to the cemetery."
SPEAKER_01: This time, the event is more relevant than usually, since president Rafael Reyes
SPEAKER_01: guided by this moment of political instability, makes an exception
SPEAKER_01: and the shooting doesn't take place in the courtyard of the School of Infantry,
SPEAKER_01: where it would normally happened.
SPEAKER_01: Instead, it's held in a public area, in front of over 10,000 people.
SPEAKER_01: Rafael Reyes saw here the remains of the last civil war
SPEAKER_01: that had ended only four years ago, and still had the country in agony.
SPEAKER_01: Shooting people of his same political party in public areas,
SPEAKER_01: was for him a sign of authority,
SPEAKER_01: but also an invitation to end the traditional divide
SPEAKER_01: between the liberal and the conservative party.
SPEAKER_01: With the purpose of making this shooting visible to as many people as possible
SPEAKER_01: Reyes publishes the book "February 10th", telling the events through photos.
SPEAKER_01: Reyes thought that, just like the people who witnessed the shooting in person did,
SPEAKER_01: everyone who saw those photos would immediately support his idea.
SPEAKER_01: Nevertheless, the most interesting part of this series of photos
SPEAKER_01: happens after the moment of the cemetery picture.
SPEAKER_01: It’s unknown whose idea it was, but due to the impact caused by the pictures of the execution
SPEAKER_01: president Rafael Reyes, Chief of police Pedro Pedraza, and photographer Lino Lara
SPEAKER_01: decided together to recreate the moments before the shooting.
SPEAKER_01: They decided to recreate the attack on the president
SPEAKER_01: and the capture of the condemned, to create a story.
SPEAKER_01: The outcome was what the historians called a "false document".
SPEAKER_01: From the 22 pictures that make up the story, 18 are theatrical reenactments.
SPEAKER_01: This is the first time of a tale made through photographs in Colombia.
SPEAKER_01: This little narrative gesture, is acknowledged by tradition
SPEAKER_01: as the beginning of filmmaking in the country.
SPEAKER_01: Here lays the body of Rafael Reyes today.
SPEAKER_01: This was going to be a movie about the beginnings of Cinema in Colombia,
SPEAKER_01: about its first images.
SPEAKER_01: But as it's being said:
SPEAKER_01: To talk about Colombia we have to talk about war.
SPEAKER_01: And to talk about war we need to talk about armies, about deaths, about cemeteries.
SPEAKER_01: At the same time, my house and my parents house looked like a cemetery.
SPEAKER_01: It felt like haunted by an inert current, like flooded by murky water
SPEAKER_01: or better, by dead water.
SPEAKER_01: A few months ago my mother had an episode of mutism,
SPEAKER_01: and without any explanation, she just stopped talking.
SPEAKER_01: I remember with some nostalgia
SPEAKER_01: how she repeated the words of that Mexican musician while cooking:
SPEAKER_01: that said something like: "I wish you to be happy, very happy...
SPEAKER_01: I wish you to find love, because you deserve it"
SPEAKER_01: I read somewhere that the first thing you forget about a person is the voice.
SPEAKER_01: Affected by this familiar incident,
SPEAKER_01: and because of what connects all things together
SPEAKER_01: maybe the first moments of national cinema
SPEAKER_01: and the muteness of my mother can be part of the same scenario.
SPEAKER_01: Like when you look at a surface where shadows are being projected
SPEAKER_01: and you can't tell each object from the other apart.
SPEAKER_01: One night my father woke up and saw the light of the bathroom on.
SPEAKER_01: When he came closer, he saw my mother in front of the mirror, shaking.
SPEAKER_01: My father hugged her and asked her what was going on,
SPEAKER_01: he asked her if she had a bad dream
SPEAKER_01: but she couldn’t answer.
SPEAKER_01: Since that moment, she has never spoken again.
SPEAKER_01: My mother spent most of the time locked in a room looking at people through the window.
SPEAKER_01: Her presence had become more and more unbearable for my father
SPEAKER_01: who couldn’t avoid feeling sometimes guilty, and sometimes cheated.
SPEAKER_01: The ambiguity of the doctors answers left a bad feeling behind
SPEAKER_01: which made him think that she was just pretending.
SPEAKER_01: One day, a worker of the family suggested to try with another type of specialist
SPEAKER_01: from his point of view, my mother's muteness was due to a powerful spell.
SPEAKER_01: My father agreed, even if it would make him feel humiliated
SPEAKER_01: because for him, superstitions were for fools.
SPEAKER_01: After two weeks some kind of chaman or warlock came to my mother.
SPEAKER_01: After wandering around the house, where some kind of weird mantle could certainly be felt
SPEAKER_01: like a thick, rancid smell, he told my father:
SPEAKER_01: "Your problems have a solution, don’t worry.
SPEAKER_01: You just have to sell this house,
SPEAKER_01: and leave somewhere visible a valuable object and a picture of her."
SPEAKER_01: My father did so.
SPEAKER_01: The house was put on sale, and on a shelf he left a picture of her
SPEAKER_01: and a black stone that she held like a luck charm.
SPEAKER_01: There’s an announcement on the internet that says:
SPEAKER_01: "Recover all important moments of your life that are kept in old tapes.
SPEAKER_01: Live those unique moments with your family and friends again.
SPEAKER_01: All formats, Betacam SP, VHS, DV, mini DV, 8mm…"
SPEAKER_01: I contacted the advertiser.
SPEAKER_01: That same afternoon, in a country house on the outskirts of the city,
SPEAKER_01: I got to meet Carlos Pelbet,
SPEAKER_01: founder of an old audiovisual company that he and his brother had
SPEAKER_01: since the beginning of the 80s.
SPEAKER_01: Carlos told me rapidly about his interest in films
SPEAKER_01: or rather, he told me that at some point of his life it was of his interest.
SPEAKER_01: Also that Pelbet, his company,
SPEAKER_01: inaugurated the recording and broadcasting business of soccer matches in Colombia
SPEAKER_01: and that it was right then, when competing with the big TV channels, that the company broke.
SPEAKER_01: He told me that a few years ago he started collecting anonymous family home movies
SPEAKER_01: from the cassettes that he digitizes. Hours and hours of family events
SPEAKER_01: weddings, first communions, birthdays, baptisms, Christmas and holidays.
SPEAKER_01: In a sense, my film is a relative of all these images,
SPEAKER_01: of the personal images of everyday rites.
SPEAKER_01: Carlos tells me that each week, a different youngster arrives at his door
SPEAKER_01: wanting to digitize images of his family
SPEAKER_01: with an idea similar to mine:
SPEAKER_01: To make a film about their mothers, fathers or grandparents.
SPEAKER_01: Apparently more people are doing the same film as me at this moment.
SPEAKER_01: We are all thinking about the same images.
SPEAKER_01: These are some images taken by my mother.
SPEAKER_01: A movie about a play in a rural school she worked at.

SPEAKER_01: Apparently, the play is about a popular narration about the first combats
SPEAKER_01: between the FARC guerilla and the National Army.
SPEAKER_01: The story is the following:
SPEAKER_01: Having the intention of avoiding the expansion of the communist guerrilla,
SPEAKER_01: on May 18th, 1964 president Guillermo León Valencia
SPEAKER_01: sends over a thousand soldiers to the Tolima plateau
SPEAKER_01: in search for a suspected FARC camp with 48 members of the insurgent movement in it.
SPEAKER_01: After nine days of intense wandering, the group of soldiers,
SPEAKER_01: lead by Lieutenant Colonel José Joaquín Matallana,
SPEAKER_01: starts suspecting that they’re wrong, that there’s no such camp.
SPEAKER_01: They quickly realize that the insurgents are not full time soldiers,
SPEAKER_01: and that most of them actually
SPEAKER_01: have a disguised life as farmers among the civilians.
SPEAKER_01: A question immediately arose:
SPEAKER_01: How to tell the population, most of them farmers, from the guerrillas apart?
SPEAKER_01: Facing this, Colonel José Joaquín Matallana,
SPEAKER_01: who considered himself as an analytic and methodic person
SPEAKER_01: and an innovating strategist, thought to have the answer.
SPEAKER_01: He explains to his soldiers: "This problem is essentially about appearances".
SPEAKER_01: Matallana ordered his soldiers to go after every man and woman of the area
SPEAKER_01: and force them to wear the guerrilla uniform in front of them.
SPEAKER_01: Matallana assured his soldiers,
SPEAKER_01: that the uniform had the strength and essential capacity
SPEAKER_01: to reveal someone's identity.
SPEAKER_01: According to his logic, wearing the uniform
SPEAKER_01: would immediately reveal if the person was a real guerilla soldier or not.
SPEAKER_01: After two weeks they had captured 52 people, including five children and eight elderly.
SPEAKER_01: This idea would be known later as the Matallana logic.
SPEAKER_01: And what could have been a brilliant military operation,
